bestBHT.bht: May the grace and peace of God be with you. In his salutation, Paul genuinely wishes for the divine grace and peace even upon those he is about to upbraid. Grace encompasses the fullness of the gospel blessing, while peace signifies the personal enjoyment and happiness derived from it. The association of God the Father and our Lord Jesus Christ highlights the divinity of Christ, who serves as the mediator of saving grace and inward peace. Without Christ, neither grace nor true prosperity can be obtained.

Henry Alford: 3.] See introductory note on Rom. i. 1–7.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: —Omit the second "from." The Greek joins God
the Father and our Lord Jesus Christ in closet union, by there being
Albert Barnes: Grace be unto you ... - This is the usual apostolic salutation, imploring for them the blessing of God. See it fully explained in the notes at Romans 1:7.
Marvin Vincent: Grace to you, etc. See on 1 Thessalonians 1:1. He will not withhold the wish for the divine grace and peace even from those whom he is about to upbraid.
John Calvin: Paul wishes for the Galatians a state of friendship with God, and, along with it, all good things."
The favor of God is the source from which we derive every kind of prosperity."
Without Christ neither grace, nor any real prosperity, can be obtained.
Philip Schaff: ‘Grace’ comprehends the fulness of the gospel blessing, ‘peace’ the fulness of our personal enjoyment of it and happiness resulting from it.

The Father is the direct giver, the Son the mediator, of saving grace and inward peace; but both are here (as in Galatians 1:1) so immediately associated that we have a right to infer from this the divinity of our Lord.
No mere man could, without blasphemy, be put into such juxtaposition with the infinite Jehovah as a giver of grace and peace.
Archibald T. Robertson: Grace to you and peace... is not a perfunctory thing with Paul."
He uses it here even when he has so much fault to find just as he did in I and II Corinthians.
But this customary salutation... is not a perfunctory thing with Paul.
John Gill: The inscription above, in which the writer of the epistle, and the persons joined to him, are described.
The salutation in these words, and which is common to all the epistles of this apostle.

bhtAttempts.bht: May the grace and peace of God be with you, for Paul's salutation of Grace to you is not perfunctory. Despite the forthcoming words of reprimand, Paul still desires the divine grace and peace for the Galatians. In this apostolic greeting, grace encompasses the fullness of the gospel blessing, while peace refers to the personal enjoyment and happiness resulting from it. The association of God the Father and our Lord Jesus Christ in the salutation highlights the divinity of Christ, who mediates the saving grace and inward peace. It is through Him that we can obtain every kind of prosperity, as without Christ, neither grace nor genuine prosperity can be attained.

May the grace and peace of God be with you. Paul's salutation of Grace to you is not perfunctory, as even when he has faults to address, he wishes for the divine grace and peace upon the Galatians. Grace encompasses the fullness of the gospel blessing, while peace refers to the personal enjoyment and happiness resulting from it. The association of God the Father and our Lord Jesus Christ underscores the divinity of Christ, who mediates saving grace and inward peace, making Him essential for attaining prosperity.

May the grace and peace of God be with you. In his salutation, Paul genuinely wishes for the divine grace and peace even upon those he is about to upbraid. Grace encompasses the fullness of the gospel blessing, while peace signifies the personal enjoyment and happiness derived from it. The association of God the Father and our Lord Jesus Christ highlights the divinity of Christ, who serves as the mediator of saving grace and inward peace. Without Christ, neither grace nor true prosperity can be obtained.

May the grace and peace of God be upon you, for Paul's salutation of Grace to you is not perfunctory. Despite the forthcoming reprimands, he earnestly desires the divine grace and peace for the Galatians. Grace encompasses the fullness of the gospel blessing, while peace signifies the personal enjoyment resulting from it. The association of God the Father and our Lord Jesus Christ highlights the divinity of Christ, who is the mediator of saving grace and inward peace. Without Christ, neither grace nor genuine prosperity can be obtained.

May the grace and peace of God be with you, for Paul's salutation of Grace to you is not perfunctory. Despite the forthcoming words of reprimand, Paul still desires the divine grace and peace for the Galatians. In this apostolic greeting, grace encompasses the fullness of the gospel blessing, while peace refers to the personal enjoyment and happiness resulting from it. The association of God the Father and our Lord Jesus Christ in the salutation highlights the divinity of Christ, who mediates the saving grace and inward peace. It is through Him that we can obtain every kind of prosperity.
